column4: This study investigated the effects of computer-assisted cooperative learning in mathematics instruction within integrated classrooms for students with and without disabilities. A total of 118, 3rd grade elementary students, 25 of whom had learning disabilities participated in the study. These students were grouped into a cooperative or whole-class learning environment to learn mathematics supported by computer technology. Six regular teachers were randomly assigned either to cooperative or whole-class learning groups to conduct mathematics instruction following the school's curriculum. Three special education teachers, with their participating students, were integrated within the regular classes. Three commercial computer software packages were used for students to learn mathematics skills, including concepts, computation, application and problem solving. The mathematics achievement was examined by pre-and posttests to the participating students. Results showed that students in the cooperative learning group had statistically higher achievement scores than those in the whole-class learning group. However, there were no significant differences between the groups of regular students on the social outcome measure. In addition, interviews of special education students indicated that they liked to be included in regular classrooms only when they were accepted and supported.

column4: 70 junior high school students practiced algebra in mixed- or uniform-ability groups, and rewards were based on individual or group performance or both. Each group worked on a computer drill together and then competed with other students in a computer game. A combination of individual and group reward facilitated peer tutoring and achievement on the algebra problems taught. Results for ability grouping are weak but do support previous research. column4: This study examined the effects of two cooperative learning treatments on the mathematics achievement and self-regulation strategies of seventh grade students in a suburban public school. The aim was to design a cooperative learning setting that would maximize its potentialities for higher order learning. Six intact classes of two teachers were randomly assigned to one of three modes of instruction, "Traditional Instruction," "Student Team Learning," and "Enhanced Cooperative Learning." The quasi-experimental design was a two by three factorial with teacher and treatment as main factors. Three criterion-based tests were administered. The first two tests consisted of both basic skills and word problems  the third consisted entirely of word problems requiring use of higher order thinking skills. Multiple regression procedures tested the hypotheses that cooperative learning is superior to traditional instruction and that the enhanced cooperative learning method is superior to the student team learning method. The statistical power of the analyses was increased by using sixth grade scores on the Metropolitan Achievement Test as a covariate. Random samples from the cooperative learning classes completed a questionnaire that measured self-regulation strategies pertinent to group work. Analyses of covariance revealed no significant differences between teachers or methods on the first test but a strong teacher effect on the second and third tests. The hypothesis that cooperative learning was superior to traditional instruction was also supported on the third test. When the data for each teacher were analyzed separately, both research hypotheses were significant for one teacher on the third test. The Student Questionnaire on Group Work, with a reliability coefficient of.90, proved a reliable and valid indicator of self-regulation strategies pertinent to cooperative group work. However, relatively low average responses on this measure suggested a need for continuing assessment and refinement of targeted social skills. The potential effectiveness of the Enhanced Cooperative Learning design may reside in better structuring of the self-regulation strategies. The results suggest that cooperative learning may be significantly more effective only after an extended period of staff development and exposure with students. Continuous evaluation of group work self-regulation strategies may point to subsequent refinements.
